title: Kepler Conjecture: Sphere Packing
description: The face-centered cubic lattice achieves the maximum sphere packing density of pi/(3*sqrt(2)). Part of Hilbert's 18th Problem, proven by Hales (1998).

overview.historicalContext: Kepler conjectured in 1611 that the FCC lattice achieves maximum sphere packing density. Hales proved this in 1998 with a computer-assisted proof, formally verified by Flyspeck (2014).
overview.problemStatement: **Theorem (Kepler-Hales):** The maximum density for sphere packing in R^3 is pi/(3*sqrt(2)) approx 74.05%, achieved by the face-centered cubic lattice.
overview.proofStrategy:
The proof involves:
1. Reducing to finite local configurations
2. Computer verification of thousands of cases
3. Formal verification in HOL Light (Flyspeck)

sections.title: 2D Sphere Packing
sections.summary: Hexagonal packing in 2D achieves optimal density.

sections.title: 3D FCC Lattice
sections.summary: Face-centered cubic lattice and the Kepler conjecture.

conclusion.summary: The Kepler Conjecture is proven: FCC achieves maximum sphere packing density. This was the first major theorem proved with computer assistance and formally verified.
conclusion.implications: The proof pioneered formal verification of computer-assisted proofs. Sphere packing has applications in coding theory and crystallography.
openQuestions: What about sphere packing in higher dimensions?
What are the applications to coding theory?
